coredata.dc:title: Vibrational energy relaxation of liquid deuterium chloride
coredata.dc:creator: Chesnoy, J.
Ricard, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The vibrational lifetime of DCI molecules has been measured in the liquid phase along the liquid—vapor coexistence curve. The results show that rotation plays an important role in vibrational relaxation of hydrogen halide liquids. They also substantiate the interpretation in terms of the role of vibrational predissociation of dimers.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: 3 September 1982 Volume 91, ninnbL'r 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LCTTCRS VIBRATIONAL ENERGY RELAXATION OF LIQUID DEUTERIUM CHLORIDE J.CHESNOYandD RICARD Lahoratoirc d'Optiqiic Qimntiqtic dii C A/ R S , Ecole Polytecimiqiie, 91128 Palaiseau Cedex, France Rci.civcil9.1unc 1982 Tlie vibr.ition.il litclinie or DCI molecules lias been measured in the liquid pliasc .ilong the liquid-vapor coc\islcnce curve. 1 lit. rcsulti sliutt Ilut roution pLusan important role in vibrationat rela\ation of hydrogen halidc liquids. They also sub- -ilJntiJlc llie inti-rpreliHion in term!, of the role of vibrJtional prcdissociation of duncrs. 1 Introduction The study ofvibMiional energy rela.\ation in the liquid pliasc is a subject or great importance. Since the development of the Rainan technique by de Martini and Queuing [ 11, llns method, whose key idea is to use spontaneous anti-Stokes Raman scattering to probe tlie population of the excited vibrational level, has al- ready been used to measure vibrational lifetimes of small molecules in dense phases [2,3] concurrently will the iJser-induced fluorescence technique [4,5]. In a previous paper [6], we reported our measure- ments of the lifetime of the first e\cited vibrational level of hydrogen clilonde in the liquid pliase and in llic dense fluid above the critical temperature. This work lias now been c\tendcd to a study of deuterium clilonde. In (lie present paper, we rcpcrt on this new measurement performed along the liquid-vapor co- existence curve and slightly above the critical point. Our main motivation in e\tendmg our measurements to DCI was to study (lie role of rotation m vibrational rela\aiion in the liquid phase. Rotation is known to play an important role in the case of low-density gas- phase HC1 and DCI [7]. These two molecules have identical intermolecular potentials, similar total masses and tlierniodynamic data (liquid densities, association equilibrium constant,...). On the other hand, they have different vibrational and rotational constants. In the hquid phase, when tlie temperature is lowered, rotation becomes more and more hindered [8]. Because of the difference in their rotational constants, more rotational levels of the free molecule DCI lie below the potential barrier than for the molecule HC1. Unfortunately, the vibrational lifetime of DCI has not been measured as a function of temperature (for low temperatures) in the low-density gas phase. It has only been measured at room temperature. It is also interesting to compare the role of vibrational predissociation ofdimers for these two molecules- hydrogen and deuterium chloride. 2. Experimental The technique we use and the apparatus have been described [6]. We sum up the main features and de- scribe the small modifications needed in the case of DCI. The technique being of the excite-and-probe type, we need two light pukes - the First one populating the excited vibrational level and the second probing its population - with a variable time delay between each other. The two light pulses are derived from a single laser pulse delivered by a mode-locked Nd : YAG laser, pulse selector and amplifier system operating at a 2.5 Hz repetition rate. Excitation is achieved via pair ab- sorption [9], the adequate infrared wavelength being generated by single-pass parametric amplification in three lithium niobate crystals. The probe pulse is gen- erated in a frequency-doubling crystal. The anti-Stokes photons are collected by a large collection solid angle asphencal lens and Filtered by a large rejection filter stack. 130 0 009-2614/82/0000-OOOO/S 02.75 1982 North-Holland Volume 91, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 3 September 1982 The spontaneous anti-Stokes signal being weaker than in the case of HC1, the focusing of the two slightly non-collinear beams has been improved down to a focal spot of 0.4 mm in diameter for the excitation beam and 0.1 mm for the probe beam. The measured lifetimes being longer, the delay line was lengthened to 2.8 m. The sample preparation is the same as in the case of HC1. After several distillations, DC1 is contained in a sealed glass bulb. Commerical deuterium chloride was purchased from Merck, Sharp and Dohme. The whole experiment is controlled by an Apple II microcomputer. 3. Results The measured vibrational lifetime of liquid DCI is shown in Fig. 1 as a function of temperature along the liquid vapor coexistence curve with one data point (A) slightly above the critical temperature. The lifetime of the v = I level increases from 3.5 ns at the triple point to "8.5 ns near the critical temperature. There are two sources of fluctuations and uncer- tainty in these results. The First one is the photon and photomultiplier noise due to the weak anti-Stokes sig- nal. Compared to HC1, this noise is considerably increa- sed because of the larger reduced mass and smaller vibrational constant which reduce both the absorption T,(n.) Fig. 1. The dots represent the vibrational lifetime T\ of deu- terium chloride in the liquid phase as a function of tempera- ture T. The measurements have been performed along the liquid-vapor coexistence curve, except foi point A (TA = 325 K, p A = 0.79 X 10" cm"3). The solid line gives the HC1 lifetime multiplied by the constant factor 4 25. and the Raman cross sections. The second source of ui certainty comes from the spontaneous anti-Stokes seal tering from the thermally excited molecules in the sample. This is due to the relatively small vibrational energy quantum of DC1. At room temperature, the frai tional population of the u= 1 levels 0.4 X lO^.'niis is not much smaller than the excitation rate used in thi experiment. And the situation gets worse near (he critical temperature where fractional thermal popula- tion and excitation rate arc about the same. This back- ground is subtracted from the measured signal, but its fluctuations give rise to noise in the true signal. The points in fig. 1 represent the average over sever; measurements carried out on two different samples. Each measurement is performed on 16 different delay times with s400 shots for each delay tune, the excita- tion beam being blocked every second shot We estima the uncertainty in the Final results given in fig. 1 to be sl0% all along the curve except when approaching the critical point where it may reach 20%. There is some possibility of a systematic error comn from the long delay line used in these measurements It could give rise to a change m the overlapping of the excitation and probe beams. To avoid this possible error, we used a probe beam having a much smaller diameter than the excitation beam (at the sample) and we also used corner cubes instead of mirrors in the delay line. The anti-Stokes signal being too weak, we were not able to study the dependence of the relaxation tune or the density above the critical temperature. Only one sample with a density close to the critical one has been studied slightly above the critical temperature. 4. Discussion The first thing we notice when we look at the result is the fact that the curves lifetime T') versus tempera- ture T along the liquid vapor coexistence curve are almost the same for HC1 and DC1 within a constant factor. In other words, they would be almost parallel o a log scale (see fig. 1). The second thing we notice is that the ratio of the measured lifetime at room temperature to the lifetime one would extrapolate linearly from the gas-phase data is the same for HC1 and DC1. More precisely, the produ of the relaxation constant fc^c measured at room tem- 131 Volume 9 l.nuinbi-r 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 3 September 1982 peraiure for HC1 gas [10] or DC1 gas [11] by the life- time 7i measured previously [6] in the case of HC1 and in the present work in (lie case of DC1 give the same result. At room temperature VlWr^bc^DCl^XlO-^cni3. We recall that such a comparison can only be performed at room temperature. Notice that the product k^T\ has dimensions of tlie inverse of a number density; this effective density (3 3 X 1022 cm"3) is larger than the density of the liquid at the same temperature [12] (1 3 X 1022 cm"3). Tilis is usual behaviour for a liquid, where the relaxation time is shorter than tlie value ob- tained from a linear extrapolation of the low-density gas-pliase data. Such a fact is due to the interplay of several physical effects" vibrationai predissociation of dimers, attractive part of tlie intermolecular potential and excluded volume. We discuss tins in more detail below. 4 I. Ttie role of rotation in vibrationai relaxation As already stated in the introduction, it is known that rotation plays an important role in vibrationai en- ergy rela\ation ofliydrogen lialide molecules in the low-density gas phase although it is probably not the only energy-accepting mode [7]. It is important to known whether or not rotation has the same impor- tant role in the liquid pliase. On the temperature range of the present experiment, tlie density varies by a factor %2. This leads to a large variation of the hinder- ing potential. If tins hindering potential affected vibra- tionai relaxation, this effect would be more pronounced in tlie case of DC1 wliere more rotational levels of the free molecule are hidden m this potential. In fact, the c\perunent shows that the ratio of the DC1 lifetime to the HC1 one is abnost constant over the whole temperature range under study. If we assume that the same is true for the ratio of the DC1 relaxation constant to tlie HC1 one, which seems likely since the reduced collisional masses are close to each other, we conclude that the role of rotation is not drastically dif- ferent in tlie liquid pliase. Experimental knowledge of (lie temperature dependence of the relaxation constant of low-density gas-pliase DC1 would of course be of prime importance. The theoretical treatments of vibrationai energy relaxation in the gas and in the liquid start usually from different approaches: binary collisions in the gas, and a bath of low-frequency degrees of freedom in the liquid (see ref. [13] for a review), which are difficult to re- concile. Our experiment confirms that, even when ro- tation is an important accepting mode, a gas-like treat- ment of the liquid avoiding the impossible a priori cal- culation must be adequate. Perhaps the wavefunction for rotation is not so different in the gas and in the liquid at the close distance of approach where relaxation takes place. This confirms the large applicability of cell models such as the Madigosky and Litovitz one (14] or more sophisticated models such as the Delalande and Gale model (IS) starting from the hypothesis that the different translation states of gas and liquid do not change the deexcitation probability per collision but only the collision frequency. One may however wonder: is there a cell effect for rotation equivalent to that appearing for translation and due to the finite volume (and non-spherical shape) of tlie molecule? 4.2. Hard core and diniers We briefly recall the assumptions used in the inter- pretation of the liquid HC1 results [6] and then look for the implications of the present results obtained on liquid DC1. We used the Gale and Delalande model which assumes an isotropic intermolecular potential consisting of a hard core of diameter o and an attractive part of depth e. The lifetime T^ in the liquid can then be obtained from the high-density gas-phase value of the relaxation constant fcg^ at the same temperature. 7f'= (l/pl \^(o)gasfe(o)llq, where p is the number density. The pair distribution function^ gives a good way of taking into account at the same time the role of the attractive forces (predominant in the gas) and the ex- cluded volume effect (predominant in the liquid). For HC1 and DC1, the thennodynamic quantities ^(o)1"1,^)635 and P1"! are identical, if we assume subtle effects to be small [16]. So the product (fcgasT'}"1) is expected to be the same for HC1 and DC1. The validity of this conclusion is not really dependent on the validity of the model. Other binary-collision theories such as a cell model [14] would have led to the same conclu- sion. 132 Volume 91, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 3 Seplcnilur 1982 What appeared to be an important feature in our in- terpretation of the HC1 results is that tlie high-density gas rate constant Agas is larger than the low-density con- stant fr^c" ^s^-bc^WA). where k(/k^ is the equilibrium constant of the dimcn/a- tion reaction ^"r M+M+M^ MM+M, *d where M is a molecule and r is the lifetime of an excited dimer (due to vibrational predissociation) Iv^M'^M+M. M* stands for a vibrationally excited molecule. In the binary-collision approximation ^ ^c. where P is the probability ofdeexcitation per collision, u is the mean relative velocity and Q(; is the colhsion cross section. In the same approximation T is given by llr=Pv, where r is the dimer vibrational frcqunecy. So, \lrk^=vlw^ is the same for HC1 and DC1 smce both v and u vary as the inverse square root of the reduced mass Here again, the conclusion is more general than the model used to derive it. If we define a parameter C as k = Ck " gas ^bc' then C should be the same for HC1 and DC1. This and the fact that ky^T\ is the same for the two molecules imply that k^T\ should be the same for HC1 and DC1. This is precisely what we observe at room temperature. It would be interesting to measure C close to the critical temperature T^ as was done in the case of HC1. Let us assume that the value offc^c near TC ls tne same as the room-temperature value (this is known to be true for HC1). From the measurement performed slightly above T^ in the case of DC1, we get the value A w 1.5 X 10-14 cm3 s-'. This would lead, near 7'g to the value C as 2.15 for DC1. In the case of HC1, we had C 2.6. The DC1 C constant would then be smaller than the HC1 one although one may argue that they agree within the uncertainty. Notice that to obtain the fcg^ value for DC1 we assume that I/T'| is proportional to the density. Such a linear dependence has been chccke for HC1 but could not be tested for DC1 If the vibra- tional mode of the dimer wlncli is relevant in the prc- dissociation process is a bending mode instead of the stretching mode, then we expect (lie DC1 C constant to be smaller than the HC1 one since, contrary to tlie total mass of tlie molecule which is only slightly cliang the moment of inertia is doubled One must however wait for a more accurate measurement before drawing any final conclusion. 5. Conclusion Tlie results of our measurements on liquid dcutenui chloride first tend to show that rotation plays the sann important role in the liquid pliase, although rotation is known to be hindered in tlicse liquids. These results also support our interpretation in terms of binary-col- lision models, taking into account tlie role of vibration predissociation ofdimers. If our interpretation is valid, sucli a measurement ol the vibrational lifetime allows a determination of (lie excited dimer dissociation time constant r Tlie qiuntii (2/T)A-i-/A(i can be deduced from our measurements whereas the equilibrium constant fcf/A'd is related to the second virial coefficient B [ 171 k^=^-B, where VQ is an excluded volume, which is four times the molecular volume at sufficiently high temperature. B has been measured [18] and kf/k^ can then be es- timated to be %:3 X 10~22 cni3, not far from the pureh theoretical calculation given in our previous article [6| This leads to T values = 15 ns for HC1 and ==60 ns for DC1. Similar measurements have been performed on liqui hydrogen bromide. They will be reported separately. Acknowledgement We are grateful to Drs. C. Flytzams, G.M. Gale and C. Conclusion Tlie results of our measurements on liquid dcutenui chloride first tend to show that rotation plays the sann important role in the liquid pliase, although rotation is known to be hindered in tlicse liquids. These results also support our interpretation in terms of binary-col- lision models, taking into account tlie role of vibration predissociation ofdimers. head.ce:title: Vibrational energy relaxation of liquid deuterium chloride

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The vibrational lifetime of DCI molecules has been measured in the liquid phase along the liquid—vapor coexistence curve. The results show that rotation plays an important role in vibrational relaxation of hydrogen halide liquids. They also substantiate the interpretation in terms of the role of vibrational predissociation of dimers.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Vibrational spectroscopy of molecular liquids and solids
